Award.AwardTitle: Science and Math Innovative Learning Environments (SMILE) for Encore Careers in Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rio Salado, an online community college, and member of the Maricopa County Community College District, in partnership with the Tempe Union High School District and the Glendale Union High School District, is establishing the Science and Math Innovative Learning Environments (SMILE) Program for Encore Careers in Education to support the recruitment, development, and support of professionals holding baccalaureate degrees in mathematics, biology, chemistry, physics or engineering in becoming secondary teachers. Noyce funds are used to provide stipends to forty STEM professionals as they transition into teaching careers in grades 7-12 mathematics and/or science classrooms in high-needs school districts in Arizona. Through the proposed hybrid format of the SMILE program, which incorporates online courses with onsite practicum and student teaching, the number and quality of mathematics and science teachers available to high-needs school districts in Arizona is being increased.

The SMILE program is based on Rio Salado College's Post-Baccalaureate Teacher Preparation Program, a one-year program designed to develop and certify new teachers who have a four-year degree in a non-education field. Online courses incorporate Arizona's teacher certification requirements in curriculum that offers the knowledge and essential skills participants need to become highly effective teachers. Onsite practicum and student teaching experiences provide opportunities to observe master teachers in the classroom and practice teaching in a monitored and mentored environment. This combination of approaches provides STEM professionals flexibility in completing courses and allows the program to recruit SMILE Scholars statewide. Under the SMILE program, courses in methods and curriculum development are enhanced to incorporate mathematics and science content based on state standards. Master Teacher Seminars, designed specifically for the SMILE program, provide insight into methods, content, and resources useful in mathematics and science classrooms. SMILE Scholars receive additional development and support throughout the preparation program and while completing the required teaching commitment. SMILE Scholars are supported through professional development opportunities which integrate teaching materials, online resources, and training programs developed by three local NSF-funded centers that provide resources for STEM education. The program also incorporates post-graduation mentoring to improve the quality and retention of SMILE Scholars in the classroom.

Integrated course enhancements, archived Master Teacher Seminars, and professional development opportunities created through the SMILE program become part of Rio Salado College's teacher preparation program and therefore are useful to future candidates. The SMILE program offers its Scholars opportunities to receive training and experience with online teaching, thus building capacity within the teacher education program and within the workforce to meet the recent call for online high schools in each Arizona school district. In particular, the SMILE program's emphasis on mathematics and science teachers promotes the development of specific content and practicum experiences in this online teaching track to address the challenges of teaching STEM content online.

In addition to recruiting, developing, and supporting forty STEM professionals to become highly qualified mathematics and science teachers, the SMILE Scholars program provides an opportunity to identify factors that affect recruitment of STEM professionals into the teaching profession; identify program activities that are particularly helpful in producing competent, confident teachers; and identify conditions that promote retention of effective mathematics and science teachers in teaching careers. The SMILE dissemination plan specifically targets community colleges and alternative certification programs that have traditionally been underutilized in preparing mathematics and science teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SMILE Project Outcomes Report

Rio Salado College, the largest of 10 community colleges in the Maricopa Community Colleges system, established the Science and Math Innovative Learning Environments (SMILE) Program for Encore Careers in Education to promote the recruitment, training, and support of STEM professional transition into teacher careers in 6th - 12th grade math and science classrooms in Arizona.  The comprehensive SMILE program, with admission/acceptance support, a 15-month teacher education for post-baccalaureate students (based on the college's Post-Baccalaureate Education Preparation program), and post-completion mentoring and support, became a pipeline which increased the number and quality of math and science teachers available to high-need school districts.  The program provided stipends of $16,500 to scholars in the program.  In receiving those scholar stipends, Noyce Scholars committed to two years of teaching in a high need school district.

The SMILE program embedded Arizona's teacher certification requirements in online curriculum that offered the knowledge and essential pedagogical skills participants needed to become highly effective teachers.  Onsite field experience and student teaching experiences provided opportunities to observe master teachers in the classroom and practice teaching in a monitored, mentored environment.  They hybrid format of the SMILE program (i.e., online courses plus onsite field experience and student teaching) allowed participants to continue working full or part-time in their STEM position as they completed online coursework.  This minimized the financial impact of participating in the program and potentially limited the participant's time of unemployment during the period required for onsite student teaching.  They hybrid format not only provided for STEM professionals flexibility in completing the course training, but it alow allowed the program to recruit SMILE Scholars from across Arizona. 

The SMILE program had support from 31 school district partners who provide master teacher mentors (master teacher mentors had at least five years of teaching experience), as well as from 20 industry/association partners who helped the program's STEM professional recruitment efforts.

The Noyce Scholars Program provided many professional development opportunities for the scholars.  Master Teacher Seminars/Workshops designed specifically for the SMILE program provided strategies for engagement for math and science classrooms, integrating technology, and interview/resume sessions, to name a few.  In addition, opportunities for the scholars to attend national and state conferences provided for collaboration and networking with other scholars and cohorts.  The Noyce Scholar Program Team organized and implemented Preparing Resumes and Job Interview Seminars which were open to all SMILE participants and extended to Rio Salado College pre-service teachers.  The involvement in these and other professional development opportunities demonstrated a strong sense of camaraderie among the Noyce Scholars and their developing professionalism. 

Most Scholars entered the program as content experts with strong technical skills, content knowledge, and understanding of science and math applications in the STEM fields; they have become teachers who are committed to inspiring students in the STEM fields.  The scholars who have been most successful also learned effective pedagogy and relational skills through the program, enabling them to engage students in science or math learning experiences.  Having new and successful teachers enter the classroom is especially critical for science and math subjects as these are some of the hardest positions to fill in Arizona.  The Noyce teachers benefit not only aspiring scientists/mathematicians but also benefit students who need those foundational skills.

This project supported 35 Noyce Scholars over six years, of which 25 completed and were certified in the 15-month program.  A majority of completers have had one or more acceptable job offers due to the high need for qualified STEM educators in Arizona.

With their certification now complete, the scholars are focused on fulfilling their two year teaching commitment in a high-need school district.  Most are on track to fulfill this commitment by June 2019 (12 scholars) or June 2020 (five scholars); eight have already met the commitment.  Of the 25 completers, 21 are teaching in Phoenix Metro area high-need schools and four scholars are teaching in Arizona rural schools. 

Following are the demographics of the 25 new teachers supported through the Rio Salado Noyce Scholars Program:

Teaching field:  16 mathematics, 9 science (biology, physics, chemistry, and general science)

Gender:  64% male, 36% female

Ethnicity: 20-White, 3-Latino(a)/Hispanic, 1-Black/African American, 1-AmericanIndia

Average Scholar's Age:  51 years
